From: Cisco IOS Configuration Fundamentals Command Reference
FuncDef: To define a character that causes a packet to be sent, use the **dispatch-character** command in line configuration mode. To remove the definition of the specified dispatch character, usethe **no** form of this command.

ParaDef.Info: Decimal representation of the desired dispatch character.
(Optional) Additional decimal representations of characters. This syntax indicates that you can define any number of characters as dispatch characters.

Examples: The following example defines the Return character (decimal 13) as the dispatch character for virtual terminal line (vty) line 4:
ExtraInfo: See the "ASCII Character Set and Hex Values" appendix for a list of ASCII characters.The **dispatch-character** command defines one or more dispatch characters that cause a packet to be sent even if the dispatch timer has not expired. Use of a dispatch character causes the Cisco IOS software to attempt to buffer characters into larger-sized packets for transmission to the remote host.Enable the **dispatch-character** command from the session that initiates the connection, not from the incoming side of a streaming Telnet session.This command can take multiple arguments, so you can define any number of characters as dispatch characters.

RelatedCmds.description: Specifies an identifier for a TCP packet dispatch state machine on a particular line.
Specifies the transition criteria for the state of a particular state machine.
Defines a character that causes a packet to be sent for the current session.
